bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 23, 1879

div1.p: Reed is concerned about his son's illness. He observes a beautiful snowfall, and gives details about a hunting trip on which Native Americans accompany him.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 23, 1879
div1.p:
I am quite tired
out and feel a little sore in my back and
bones, to-night, but I must write at
least a page to my darling Emilie before
I go to-bed- I have just returned from
a hunting expedition of 7 days duration;
got home, this afternoon, about 2 o'clock,
after riding the whole day, since early
morning, in a blinding snow-storm -- a
real Christmas, Santa Claus snow-storm
“one that you read about in the books”,
lovie- But I'll wait till to-morrow morn-
-ing before giving you an account of
our wonderful hunt- Your precious
letter of Decr 4th was here waiting for
me, and before I had finished reading
the first page, Oh! how my very heart
yearned in heart-felt pity and sym-
-pathy for my precious wife sitting
by the bed-side of our darling little
son and watching and waiting and praying
through the long hours of the day & the longer
ones of night! Oh! my darling wifie,
how your poor heart must have been
weighed down with its burden of anx-
-iety and fear, lest our precious boy should
have been taken from us! Oh! with what a
grateful heart, I shall, this night, kneel
in prayer to God, who has, in his infinite
goodness and mercy spared our sweet boy's
life! Words cannot express the sense of grat-
itude with which my heart is overflowing!
If I could only have been with my own
loved wifie, to have shared the burden with
her, & to have kissed away her tears! Love
your precious life! You did just right in
not mentioning Lawrence's sickness, until
he had recovered, for my very existence
would have been one of misery! I could
not have spent one happy hour during
the week! Follow strictly Dr Moore's direc-
tions in all things- Please, Emilie, darling,
thank him, for me, for his kindness and atten-
tion to Lawrence, but do not insult him
by offering to pay him- He is an estima-
-ble physician, & such a thing as charging
for attendance on a brother-physician's
family would be unheard of! Don't
fail to thank him kindly, (as I know you
have done,) and when you have done this,
you have taken all the steps necessary
in the matter- It may seem strange to
you to not to pay your physician, but re-
-member, my darling, that your are a
physician's wife, and the ethics of the med-
-ical profession require of all physicians,
of good standing, to attend other physicians'
family free of charge! Dr Moore Cannot
expect you to pay him,- Indeed, I know
he has not given the matter a thought!
and would be surprised, and perhaps, offended,
should you ask for a bill! Bear in mind
what I have said, my precious wife, and
never bother your head about medical
bills. I would write more, to-night, but
I am so tired & sleepy, darling wifie, that
I must go to bed early- Good-night my
sweet wifie & son, and may guardian an-
gels watch over your slumbers till the
morning comes! Decr 24th 1879. 7 O'clock. A.M.
You see, my pretty wifie, that I am up bright
and early writing to my darling “Nemps”- I
thought that I would write, while Dr Mc
Pherson was over attending Sick-call.
I wish you could see the old Apache
parade, this morning. It looks as if
some one had emptied over it a few
Sacks of the choicest “family flour”- No, I will
retract that expression, for it is a shame to
liken so beautiful a sight to any of man's
doings- Everything that the eye can take in
is covered with a mantle of the purest white.
What a multitude of imperfections Nature
has covered up during the night- Even
“Laundry Row”, where so many “fine gals”
are said to dwell, presents a “most char-
-ming” appearance- You might imagine,
my darling wifie, that the huts had been
transformed into palaces, in a single night,
and instead of the “Swan-necked” Hosey and “Mrs.
Mahoney, dear”, living therein & lingering over
the pensive wash-tub, that knights & ladies
made merry music there! “I want to know”-
Our old back-yard, with its giant kitchen,
and meandering walks & embowered water
shed & various other objects of interest
which I need not mention, but with which
my darlings “Nemps” is sufficiently familiar
resembles very much the loveliest spot
in Central Park, New York- What shall I
say of the pines on the mountain sides?
“those tall, majestic pines”, how grace-
-fully & proudly they nod & droop their heads
this morning, & how their diamond-bedecked
limbs branches sparkle & glitter! Real Christ-
mas weather, my darling wifie & husband
only hopes that every thing looks as beautiful
in Norfolk this blessed 24 th of Decr 1879.
(Page. 5) You will remember, my darling wifie,
that my last letter was not a very long one,
and it was for the reason that I was in a big
hurry, getting ready for a “big” hunt with Lt.
Kingsbury and Cruse, although I did not mention
it, at the time- Well, we got away from the Post,
about 8 o'clock on Wednesday Morning, and away
we hied to “Bonito Fork”, the scene of our former
hunting expedition, on which occasion, the deer we
killed & the turkey we slew would not have
furnished fresh meat for many. On this oc-
casion, however, besides four soldiers & four
packers we had 20 of the Indian Company-
So that when we arrived at our camp, that af-
-ternoon, we found four turkey & a fine big deer
already awaiting our “molars”- We pitched our
tent under some beautiful, tall pines very near
the stream which, at night, when the moon had arisen,
sang us to sleep, as the poets say- The fact is
wifie, dear, we didn't require any gentle lullaby
to woo the Coy “Josephus”, to our heavy lids, for
twenty miles steady jogging over a rough trail
& on a mule, prepared us for a good night's
rest- Our little camp looked real pretty at
night- we were on the extreme right -- then
came our soldiers camp, about 30 feet away
& then the packers, & farther still the 20 Indians
divided into two camps of 10 each -- so that
there were five fires burning brightly, and
stretched along in a line about 30 feet apart-
we had a good tent for ourselves & one for
the soldiers- You should have seen our beds - my
darling wifie- Lt. Cruse and I dug a small hole
on each side of the tent, large enough to ad-
mit our back-bones, & then filled them with
long, dry grass which we cut from the
Mountain side, thus making a delightfully
soft cushion for our bones -- a sort of hair
mattress with springs, as it were, over which
we spread our blankets- I slept with 4 blank-
ets under me, doubled once, & 8 over me &
with my night-cap & a good heavy comfor-
ter, which Mrs. Harrison gave me, around my
neck, I managed to excude the cold, lovie, dear
pretty well- I forgot to say that I had Lt.
Kingsbury's dog sleeping on my feet to keep
them warm- And pretty cold it was, too, my
darling- Next morning, (Thursday) when we got
up bright & early we found about 1/2 an
inch of ice & the winds was singing merrily
through the trees- The Indians had already
skipped out for a day's hunt, & while we
ate our broiled venison for supper breakfast
we now & then heard a sharp crack of
a rifle, which we knew meant either a
turkey or a deer- After breakfast was over,
(I am sorry to say, darling, wifie, that I did
not wash my face, that morning, for it was
so cold!) Lt. Cruse & I took our guns & climb-
-ed a high hill, which took the breath
clean out of us, & then away wen went, tram-
-ping over the roughest Country you almost
ever saw, lovie, & we kept our walk till 2 P.M.
but we didn't get anything, as the Indians were
ahead of us & frightened all the game away.
We got back, at 2 P.M. to camp, & such a dinner
as we two ate, would have supplied a half
dozen hungry men- Lt. Cruse is “some pump-
-kins” on eating, & as “I wasn't feeling very
well”, darling wifie, & besides didn't like to
be outdone by a 2nd Lt., I “spec” I “eat
a real peart” quantity of victuals- By the
time we had finished our “little” lunch, the
Indians began to come in with their game,
& before the sun had sunk beneath the west-
-ern horizon, (Hesche!) we counted 13 deer &
10 Turkeys, as the result of one day's hunting.
I attended to “drawing” the turkeys -- in fact did
it all myself, & Lt. Kingsbury superintended
cleaning the deer- Before night we had them
all hung up on a rope stretched between
two tall pines, & by the light & glimmer of
the camp fire, the display of game was
very fine- We rather flattered ourselves, that
we had done very fair work, for one day's
hunting- That night we slept like “tops”, each
one fairly stupefied with a stomach full of
fresh meat- Friday morning, we were up before
the stars ceased shining, busy taking down our
tent & bundling up our baggage, ready for a
day's journey to another branch of Black River,
about 7 miles farther away- We were there
& in camp by 12 o'clock, noon, & after camp was
pitched, we lay off, on our backs, & “snoozed” &
ate -- & sang songs & had a jolly time generally-
That afternoon the Indians brought in 5 turkey
& 6 deer, & reported that they had left hanging
out in the trees, from 5 to 15 miles away, 13
more big deer -- so large that they couldn't
pack them in on their backs- That night
we had a glorious time broiling venison
over the hot oak coals- We ate & ate, &
yet did not seem to have enough- We held
a council of war that night & decided to send in to the
Post, next morning, sixteen deer & seventeen
Turkeys, as “a gentle reminder” to the folks
at Apache that we were, as good hunters
as other people. After getting the party off
to Apache, early next morning, (Saturday) we
started in various directions to get the deer
(Page 9.) that were hanging out- Sam Bow-
man & I went out with two pack mules
& after travelling about 15 miles over mountains
& cañons, we brought in 4 beautiful deer:- but
such a tramp as we had, my darling wife!
The Indian who went to show us where the
deer were, said it was only “poco lejos,”
that is, “a little far”- (“Dandy-Bill”, our old friend,
by the way, was the “Caballiero”,) and I never knew
what “poco lejos” was before, but I know now-
It means about 50 miles for a white man! I
was so tired when I got back to camp, that it
took about 3 lbs. of venison stew to refreshen
my drooping spirits! Saturday night, it began
to storm & rained hard all night & continued
so to do all day Sunday, so that no hunting could
be done by the Indians- All day we lay
in our tent with a roaring big fire in
front & did not dare go out, except for meals,
which even the storm could not keep
us from. About 4 P.M. on Sunday, I longed
very much to get back to Apache, so that I
might get my precious wifie's letters & read
them, & I had to smother several real
big sighs, lovie, dear- We concluded that
night that our hunt was over as the storm
only increased in severity, & we only waited
for the return of the pack mules from
Apache, in order to pack up our “duds” and
hie to the Campo- They returned on Monday,
too late for a start back on the same day-
On Tuesday morning (yesterday), however, we
started back to Apache & faced a terrible
snow-storm till 2 P.M- The tip of my
“ittle posig”, lovie, like to have frozen off,
but I kept up a brave heart, as I knew
that I would find a darling letter awaiting me,
& sure enough I did- In all we killed 41 deer
& 26 Turkeys! This morning, we distributed the
game, & now everyone, at the Post, has enough
fresh meat for their Christmas dinner- I have
not seen either Mrs. Hentig or Mrs. Harrison
since I got back -- will call there, to-night-
Col. Carr, 6th cav. & Lt. Carter (old “good Lord”!)
will be here on the 26th- Mrs. Harrison did not
get down to Lowell, as she had expected, and is
very blue accordingly- Mrs. Hentig is still sick in
bed- This letter is written on Wednesday, lovie, & hence
I will have to send it by way of Camp
Thomas- I hope it will reach my darling in
good time- I will send a check, lovie, just as soon
as the Paymaster gets here- A thousand happy
New Years for my sweet wifie & son- Papa sends
a bushels of love to both of his darlings- 3 pecks for Mama
& one peck for son-

closer.salute:
God bless & preserve you both
is ever the prayer of your fond & devoted husband,
